H0.text: A physical characteristic is the bright coloration of the insect that tastes bad, which a bird eats and then avoids preying on again.

H1.text: A learned behavior is illustrated by a bird eating a brightly‑colored insect that tastes bad and then avoiding preying on this type of insect again.

H2.text: An inherited behavior is demonstrated by a bird that eats a brightly-colored insect that tastes bad and then avoids preying on this type of insect again.

H3.text: An adaptation is the best description for a bird that eats a brightly-colored insect that tastes bad and then avoids preying on this type of insect again.

A4.text: Animals that consume a bait laced with an undetectable dose of an aversion agent avoid both baits and live prey with the same taste and scent as the baits.

A5.text: Common vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus) do not learn taste aversions despite being closely related to other species of bats that do.

A6.text: Birds recall and avoid objects that are both conspicuous and foul‑tasting longer than objects that are equally foul‑tasting but cryptically coloured.

A7.text: The mechanism of defence relies on the memory of the would‑be predator; a bird that has once experienced a foul‑tasting grasshopper will endeavor to avoid a repetition of the experience.
